title: Arizona's Water Systems
subtitle: A journey along the engineered rivers that sustain a desert metropolis.
footer:
This story is based on presentations and information from:
Jacob Richardson, Salt River Project
Brian Buzard, Central Arizona Project
Ryan Johnson, Central Arizona Water Conservation District
Tom Buschatzke, Arizona Department of Water Resources (ADWR)

Salt River Project (SRP) | Central Arizona Project (CAP)
Developed by Kshitij Dahal (kdahal3@asu.edu)

chapters.title: Water in the Desert
chapters.description: Arizona's vibrant cities and farms exist because of two monumental water projects. This story explores the journey of water through the Central Arizona Project and the Salt River Project—the systems that make life in the Sonoran Desert possible.

chapters.title: The Heart of the System: Hoover Dam & Lake Mead
chapters.description: Our story begins here, at the heart of the Colorado River system. Hoover Dam holds back Lake Mead, which acts as the 'gas gauge' for the entire Southwest. The water level here dictates who gets water and who gets cut during a shortage.

chapters.title: The Lifeline: The Central Arizona Project
chapters.description:
A 336-mile aqueduct defying gravity to deliver Colorado River water across the state. This entire system's supply is dependent on the health of Lake Mead.

The blue line is the CAP canal, orange dots are pumping plants, and green dots are recharge facilities.

chapters.title: The Intake: Lake Havasu
chapters.description: Just downstream from Hoover Dam, the journey begins. The CAP diverts a portion of the river's flow at Lake Havasu, pumping it uphill to begin its long trek south. The scale of the engineering is immense.

chapters.title: Following the Flow
chapters.description: The water doesn't flow on its own. A series of powerful pumping plants lifts it over 2,900 feet. As we fly south, the faint line of the canal carves its way through the desert, a man-made river on an epic journey.

chapters.title: The Local Powerhouse: The Salt River Project
chapters.description: Harnessing local rivers, the SRP is a separate, older, and more resilient system. It manages the Salt and Verde watershed, providing a critical water source independent of the Colorado River.

chapters.title: The Salt River System: A Staircase of Lakes
chapters.description: The backbone of the SRP is the Salt River itself, managed by a series of four dams that descend in elevation, creating a 'staircase of lakes' and providing hydroelectric power along the way. We'll start at the top.

chapters.title: Salt Dam 1: Theodore Roosevelt (1911)
chapters.description: The cornerstone of the entire system. Roosevelt Dam forms the largest reservoir, providing the vast majority of the storage capacity for the Salt River and symbolizing the dawn of large-scale water reclamation in the West.

chapters.title: Salt Dam 2: Horse Mesa (1927)
chapters.description: Downstream from the vast expanse of Roosevelt Lake, Horse Mesa Dam creates the long, narrow Apache Lake. This dam is a hydroelectric workhorse for the system.

chapters.title: Salt Dam 3: Mormon Flat (1925)
chapters.description: Next, Mormon Flat Dam impounds Canyon Lake. It features a powerful pumped-storage capability, allowing it to act like a giant battery by pumping water back uphill during times of low energy demand.

chapters.title: Salt Dam 4: Stewart Mountain (1930)
chapters.description: The final gateway to the valley. Stewart Mountain Dam forms the popular Saguaro Lake and is the last stop before water is released into the canals that feed the Phoenix metro area.

chapters.title: The Verde River System
chapters.description: The other major branch of the SRP is the Verde River, controlled by two key dams. To the north lies Horseshoe Reservoir, and just downstream, Bartlett Reservoir.

chapters.title: Verde Dam 1: Horseshoe (1946)
chapters.description: The journey down the Verde begins at Horseshoe Dam. As the most upstream reservoir, its primary role is to capture and store precious runoff from the watershed to the north.

chapters.title: Verde Dam 2: Bartlett (1939)
chapters.description: Further south, Bartlett Dam stands as an engineering landmark. At the time of its completion, it was the highest multiple-arch dam in the world, regulating flows before the Verde joins the Salt River.

chapters.title: Part 3: The New Reality of Policy, People, and Price
chapters.description: This physical system is managed by a complex web of agencies, but now faces a new reality: a historic drought that is changing the rules of the game.

chapters.title: A System Under Stress
chapters.description: The 'bathtub ring' around Lake Mead is a stark visual of the problem. Decades of drought and overuse mean we have consistently promised more water than the river can provide. This has forced drastic cuts, especially to the Central Arizona Project.

chapters.title: The First to be Cut
chapters.description: The rules of the CAP are clear: in a shortage, farmers are the first to lose their water. Since 2022, the water supply for agricultural districts in Central Arizona, seen here, has been cut to nearly zero.

chapters.title: From Farms to Faucets
chapters.description: To secure their future, cities are now buying water rights directly from farmers. Two recent deals highlight this trend: one for river water from the Cibola Valley, and another for groundwater from the Harquahala Valley.

chapters.title: The Seller: Irrigation Districts
chapters.description: An irrigation district farmer in Cibola Valley with senior river rights found it more profitable to sell that water to a city for over $12,000 per acre-foot than to grow crops. This water is more reliable than the CAP's supply.

chapters.title: The Premium: Groundwater Reliability
chapters.description: The Harquahala Valley deal is even more telling. Because this groundwater is not connected to the Colorado River, it has a 'higher reliability' and a much higher price—nearly $20,000 per acre-foot. It will be transported to cities using the CAP canal as a 'water highway'.

chapters.title: The Heroes: Tribal Nations
chapters.description: The most powerful players in this new market are Arizona's Native American Nations. Their water rights are the oldest and most senior, guaranteed by federal law. As others face cuts, they are now key partners, getting paid to conserve water and leave it in Lake Mead—acting as a critical buffer that has saved the entire system from collapse.

chapters.title: An Engineered Oasis
chapters.description: The story of Arizona's water is no longer just about engineering. It's about economics, collaboration, and adaptation. The result of a century of work is this thriving metropolis, a testament to human ingenuity but also a profound reminder of our responsibility to manage a finite resource in an arid land.
